label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Andrews, Esquire, Assistant United States Attorney of the UNITED

text: STATES DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, Wilmington, Delaware.

label: BODY

text: MEMORANDUM OPINION
label: HH1

text: Wilmington, Delaware
label: BODY

text: Farnan, District Judge.
label: HH1

text: Pending before the Court is a Motion To Renew Motion Under
label: BODY

text: 28 U.S.C. § 2255 And For Leave To Amend Motion Under 28 U.S.C. §
label: BODY

text: 2255 (D.I. 200) filed by Defendant, Thomas E. Flaherty.  For the
label: BODY

text: reasons set forth below, the Court will grant Defendant’s Motion
label: BODY

text: To Renew his Section 2255 Motion (D.I. 200), grant Defendant’s
label: BODY

text: Motion For Leave To Amend his Section 2255 Motion (D.I. 200) and
label: BODY

text: deny Defendant’s Amended Section 2255 Motion (D.I. 189, 200).
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND
label: HH1

text: On November 15, 1990, Defendant was indicted on various drug
label: BODY

text: charges.  Following a jury trial, Defendant was convicted of two
label: BODY

text: charges, conspiracy to distribute cocaine in violation of 21
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. § 846 and distribution of cocaine in violation of 21
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. §§ 841(a)(1), (b)(1)(C) and 18 U.S.C. § 2.  On November
label: BODY

text: 15, 1991, Defendant was sentenced to 360 months imprisonment to
label: BODY

text: run concurrently on the two charges.  In sentencing Defendant,
label: BODY

text: the Court concluded that Defendant was a “career offender”
label: BODY

text: pursuant to Section 4B1.1 of the United States Sentencing
label: BODY

text: Guidelines (the “Guidelines”).  The Court based its determination
label: BODY

text: upon Defendant’s previous convictions for a crime of violence and
label: BODY

text: a controlled substance offense.
label: BODY

text: On April 14, 1997, Defendant filed a Section 2255 Motion.
label: BODY

text: (D.I. 189).  By his Motion, Defendant sought to collaterally
label: BODY

text: attack a state court conviction that had been used to enhance his
label: BODY

text: Defendant filed a Motion For Expansion Of Time (D.I.
label: BODY

text: 205) to file a Reply Brief.  However, Section 2255 and the Rules
label: BODY

text: Governing Section 2255 Proceedings do not contemplate the filing
label: BODY

text: federal sentence under Section 4B1.1 of the Guidelines.  In his
label: BODY

text: Motion, Defendant indicated that he had a state court collateral
label: BODY

text: challenge pending and that he filed his Section 2255 motion to
label: BODY

text: preserve his right to seek Section 2255 relief if he was
label: BODY

text: successful in his state court proceedings.
label: BODY

text: Thereafter, the Court ordered Defendant to advise the Court
label: BODY

text: of the status of his motion for state post-conviction relief.
label: BODY

text: (D.I. 193).  Defendant filed a letter in response to the Court
label: BODY

text: indicating that the motion was denied without a hearing, but an
label: BODY

text: appeal was filed.  Defendant represented that, as of November
label: BODY

text: 1998, his appeal was still pending in the state court system.
label: BODY

text: Although several months transpired, the Court received no
label: BODY

text: further updates on the progress of Defendant’s appeal.  As a
label: BODY

text: result, the Court denied Defendant’s pending Section 2255 Motion
label: BODY

text: with leave to renew upon the disposition of Defendant’s state
label: BODY

text: court action.  (D.I. 198).  Shortly thereafter, Defendant filed
label: BODY

text: the instant Motion renewing his Section 2255 Motion and seeking
label: BODY

text: to amend the Motion to add a claim under Apprendi v. New Jersey,
label: BODY

text: The Government has filed a response to Defendant’s Renewed
label: BODY

text: Section 2255 Motion and his Motion For Leave To Amend.  (D.I.
label: BODY

text: 204).1  Accordingly, the instant Motion is ripe for the Court’s
label: BODY

text: of a traverse by the movant in response to the Government’s
label: BODY

text: answer, except in special circumstances.  In this case, the Court
label: BODY

text: finds that the issues are straightforward and capable of
label: BODY

text: resolution on the record currently before the Court.  As such,
label: BODY

text: the Court concludes that a traverse by Defendant is not
label: BODY

text: warranted, and therefore, Defendant’s Motion For Expansion Of
label: BODY

text: Time will be denied.  See e.g. United States v. Sanchez, 2002 WL
label: BODY

text: 465297 (E.D. Pa. Mar. 21, 2002) (denying defendant’s request for
label: BODY

text: leave to file a traverse where issues were straightforward and
label: BODY

text: capable of being resolved on the record before the court).
label: BODY

text: review.
label: BODY

text: DISCUSSION
label: HH1

text: Defendant’s Motion To Amend His Section 2255 Motion To
label: HH1

text: Include An Apprendi Claim
label: BODY

text: In renewing his previously filed Section 2255 Motion,
label: BODY

text: Defendant seeks to amend his Motion to include a claim that his
label: BODY

text: sentence was invalid under Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466
label: BODY

text: In determining whether Defendant should be permitted to
label: BODY

text: amend his original Section 2255 Motion to add an Apprendi claim,
label: BODY

text: the Court must consider Rule 15 of the Federal Rules of Civil
label: BODY

text: Procedure.  Riley v. Taylor, 62 F.3d 86, 89 (3d Cir. 1995).  Rule
label: BODY

text: 15(a) provides that a party may amend his pleading once as a
label: BODY

text: matter of course any time before a responsive pleading is filed.
label: BODY

text: When amendment as a matter of course is not permitted, a party
label: BODY

text: may amend his pleadings by obtaining leave of court, which should
label: BODY

text: be freely given.
label: BODY

text: Relying on United States v. Duffus, 174 F.3d 333, 337-338
label: BODY

text: (3d Cir.), cert. denied, 528 U.S. 866 (1999), the Government
label: BODY

text: opposes Defendant’s Motion To Amend on the ground that his
label: BODY

text: amendment does not relate back to his original claims, but adds
label: BODY

text: an entirely new claim.  However, the Duffus decision relied on
label: BODY

text: that portion of Rule 15 requiring leave of court to amend.  In
label: BODY

text: this case, however, it appears to the Court that Defendant sought
label: BODY

text: to add his Apprendi claim prior to the time that the Government
label: BODY

text: filed its responsive pleading.  As such, Defendant was permitted
label: BODY

text: to amend his petition as a matter of course to advance an
label: BODY

text: Apprendi claim.  Accordingly, the Court will grant Defendant’s
label: BODY

text: Motion For Leave To Amend his Section 2255 Motion.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH1

text: Defendant’s Amended Section 2255 Motion
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Apprendi Claim
label: BODY

text: By his renewed Section 2255 Motion, Defendant contends that
label: BODY

text: his sentence is invalid under Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S.
label: BODY

text: 466 (2000).  Specifically, Defendant contends that he was
label: BODY

text: convicted of two drug counts that did not specify the amount of
label: BODY

text: cocaine and that he was sentenced to a term of imprisonment that
label: BODY

text: exceeded the statutory maximum in violation of Apprendi.
label: BODY

text: In Apprendi, the United States Supreme Court held that
label: BODY

text: “[o]ther than the fact of a prior conviction, any fact that
label: BODY

text: increases the penalty for a crime beyond the prescribed statutory
label: BODY

text: maximum must be submitted to a jury, and proved beyond a
label: BODY

text: reasonable doubt.”  Id. at 490.  The Court of Appeals for the
label: BODY

text: Third Circuit has recently concluded that Apprendi does not apply
label: BODY

text: retroactively to cases on collateral review.  In re Turner, 267
label: BODY

text: F.3d 225, 231 (3d Cir. 2001) (joining majority view that Apprendi
label: BODY

text: is not retroactive); United States v. Robinson, 2001 WL 840231
label: BODY

text: (D. Del. Jul. 20, 2001) (Farnan, J.) (collecting cases).
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the Court concludes that Defendant is not entitled
label: BODY

text: to relief on his Apprendi claim.
label: BODY

text: In the alternative, however, even if the Supreme Court were
label: BODY

text: to subsequently make Apprendi retroactive to cases on collateral
label: BODY

text: review, the Court would conclude, as a substantive matter, that
label: BODY

text: Defendant has failed to establish a claim for a violation of
label: BODY

text: Apprendi.  In this case, Defendant was convicted of two drug
label: BODY

text: counts that did not specify the quantity of drugs.  As such, the
label: BODY

text: mandatory minimum provisions of Section 21 U.S.C. § 841(b)(1)
label: BODY

text: were not invoked.  Rather, Defendant was sentenced in accordance
label: BODY

text: with 21 U.S.C. § 841(b)(1)(C) and 21 U.S.C. § 851, because he had
label: BODY

text: a prior drug conviction.  Pursuant to 21 U.S.C. § 841(b)(1)(C),
label: BODY

text: Defendant was subject to a maximum period of incarceration of 30
label: BODY

text: years imprisonment on each count.  In this case, Defendant was
label: BODY

text: sentenced to thirty years imprisonment to run concurrently on
label: BODY

text: both of his convictions.  Because Defendant’s sentence did not
label: BODY

text: exceed the statutory maximum penalty that he was subject to as a
label: BODY

text: result of his prior conviction, the Court concludes that
label: BODY

text: Defendant cannot establish a violation of Apprendi.  United
label: BODY

text: States v. Pressler, 256 F.3d 144, 159 (3d Cir. 2001); United
label: BODY

text: States v. Butch, 256 F.3d 171, 180 (3d Cir. 2001) (requiring
label: BODY

text: under first prong of Apprendi inquiry that defendant’s sentence
label: BODY

text: exceed the “prescribed statutory maximum”); see also United
label: BODY

text: (“Apprendi does not require us to reverse where a sentence is
label: BODY

text: equal to the statutory maximum.”).  Accordingly, the Court will
label: BODY

text: dismiss Defendant’s claim that his sentence violated Apprendi.
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Claim That He Was Sentenced Based On A
label: BODY

text: Constitutionally Invalid Prior Conviction
label: BODY

text: In renewing his Section 2255 Motion, Defendant also requests
label: BODY

text: the Court to adjudicate the claim he initially advanced, i.e.
label: BODY

text: that his sentence was enhanced by a prior state court conviction
label: BODY

text: in Massachusetts that is constitutionally invalid.  (D.I. 189).
label: BODY

text: In his renewed Motion and attached affidavit, Defendant does not
label: BODY

text: expand on this claim other than to inform the court of the
label: BODY

text: disposition of his collateral attack.  Specifically, Defendant
label: BODY

text: states that he was unsuccessful in pursuing his collateral attack
label: BODY

text: in the Massachusetts appellate court.  As for his appeal to the
label: BODY

text: Massachusetts Supreme Court, Defendant contends that his appeal
label: BODY

text: was rejected because it was not properly formatted and his
label: BODY

text: counsel did not submit a corrected application.  (D.I. 200,
label: BODY

text: Flaherty Aff. at ¶¶ 1-4).
label: BODY

text: The United States Supreme Court has held that a defendant
label: BODY

text: cannot collaterally attack a previous state court conviction used
label: BODY

text: to enhance a federal sentence through a federal Section 2255
label: BODY

text: Defendant has not informed the Court of the grounds
label: BODY

text: upon which he challenged his prior state court conviction in
label: BODY

text: either his original Section 2255 Motion or his renewed Motion,
label: BODY

text: but Defendant has acknowledged that he “has no valid grounds to
label: BODY

text: base his section 2255 motion unless he receives a favorable
label: BODY

text: decision in the state court either modifying or vacating the
label: BODY

text: state conviction used to enhance his federal sentence.”  (D.I.
label: BODY

text: 189 at 6) (emphasis in original).  Accordingly, the Court does
label: BODY

text: not believe that the Gideon exception applies in this case.
label: BODY

text: Further, because Defendant has not provided the Court with any
label: BODY

text: information about his state court conviction, the Court does not
label: BODY

text: believe Defendant is trying to use the instant Section 2255
label: BODY

text: Motion to substantively attack that conviction.
label: BODY

text: proceeding.  Daniels v. United States, 532 U.S. 374, 382-383
label: BODY

text: (2001).  This rule applies to all federal constitutional
label: BODY

text: challenges to the state court conviction, except for a challenge
label: BODY

text: that the conviction was obtained in violation of the Sixth
label: BODY

text: Amendment right to court-appointed counsel established in Gideon
label: BODY

text: v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335 (1963).  Id. at 382.  (“A defendant
label: BODY

text: may challenge a prior conviction as the product of a Gideon
label: BODY

text: violation, in a 2255 motion, but generally only if he raised that
label: BODY

text: claim at his federal sentencing proceeding.”).2
label: BODY

text: To challenge a state court conviction used to enhance a
label: BODY

text: federal sentence, the defendant must pursue the remedies
label: BODY

text: available for that conviction, i.e. direct appeal, post-
label: BODY

text: conviction proceedings under state law and habeas corpus relief
label: BODY

text: pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2254.  Id. at 381.  If the defendant is
label: BODY

text: successful in such a challenge, the defendant may then apply to
label: BODY

text: reopen his federal sentence.  Id. at 381-382.  However, if the
label: BODY

text: prior conviction is no longer open for direct or collateral
label: BODY

text: attack because the defendant failed to pursue his remedies or was
label: BODY

text: unsuccessful in pursing them, then the conviction is
label: BODY

text: presumptively valid and may be used to enhance the defendant’s
label: BODY

text: federal sentence.  Id.
label: BODY

text: Based on Defendant’s affidavit, it appears that he was
label: BODY

text: unsuccessful in challenging the state court conviction used to
label: BODY

text: enhance his federal sentence in the Massachusetts state courts.
label: BODY

text: Should Defendant be successful at some point in the future in
label: BODY

text: challenging that conviction through Section 2254 proceedings or
label: BODY

text: renewed state court proceedings, he can petition the Court to
label: BODY

text: reopen his federal sentence.  At this point, however, Defendant
label: BODY

text: has not established that the state court conviction used to
label: BODY

text: enhance his federal sentence was invalid.  Accordingly, the Court
label: BODY

text: will dismiss Defendant’s claim to the extent that it challenges
label: BODY

text: the state court conviction used to enhance his federal sentence.
label: BODY

text: CONCLUSION
label: HH1

text: For the reasons discussed, the Court will grant Defendant’s
label: BODY

text: Motion To Renew his Section 2255 Motion, grant Defendant’s Motion
label: BODY

text: For Leave To Amend and deny Defendant’s Amended Section 2255
label: BODY

text: Motion (D.I. 189, 200).
label: BODY

text: An appropriate Order will be entered.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that:
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2255 (D.I. 200) is GRANTED.
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Motion For Leave To Amend Motion Under 28
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. § 2255 (D.I. 200) is GRANTED.
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Amended Motion To Vacate Sentence Under 28
label: BODY

text: Because the Court finds that Defendant has not made “a
label: BODY

text: substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right”
label: BODY

text: under 28 U.S.C. § 2253(c)(2), a certificate of appealability is
label: BODY

text: DENIED.
